values: Wouldn't you like to be an inflatable sun, too?
Sarah McLachlan photo by scott mellgren
On the first night of their tour, we happened to do a photo shoot. It's a good thing I brought lights. Jill is a great lighting assistant.

Over 30 miles away was a tornado in this storm near Jones, Spencer or Luther directions as Gary England told me on the radio while I skipped work to take this image a week ago. This is shot on Rock Creek Rd west of 48th Ave NW, the only place I could see the horizon worth a republican within minutes of my studio location.

Do you have any data recovery suggestions?
I starting the night with a couple of quick shots before I realized that the card I had selected for the evening was full. I scanned the first few on the card and knew they were duplicated at home.
I formatted. Shot all night. Filled the card, quit shooting (usually at least 140 shots on that full card). 50 is just an estimate, not exact.
The camera says it only had 2 exposures left but only 67 are reviewable. So really there could be 100 missing in that directory.

The lengths I will go through. A concert in Tulsa at Cain's Ballroom. On a Wednesday (I have to work at 8:00am the next morning). So, I drive up to Tulsa after work, about a two-hour drive. Along the way, it's raining. I hydroplane for about 30 miles with a maximum speed of 45-50mph. I finally get there and Crisis is already on stage. Then it's Otep. Then, Kittie. Morgan Lander is the best thing since James Hetfield. That's why I do it.

My brother-in-law, who lives 20 minutes from the venue, meets me there. It's nice to have a photo pass and be on the guest list. It helps to offset the $7.00 in turnpike fees (round trip from Oklahoma City to Tulsa). When I first walk in, Morgan is near the door signing autographs. I fall in line since, after all, I am a true fan. I hand off some photos (1,2,3) that I took of Kittie back in July when they played in Oklahoma City, which is the most fun I've ever had shooting bands, that's why I do it. She says, "Where'd you get these??" I explained that I took them. I had printed one specifically for her to autograph (2), but she wanted that one, too. That's cool, so I have her sign another image which I happened to have brought two copies with me.

Again, it was a lot of fun and well worth my efforts. I enjoyed all the acts on the "Metal Movement Tour 2004." It's not often that you see a metal/screamo/thrash/death/speed band fronted by a female. On this night there were three of them. Sweet. It rocked and I can't wait to see Kittie again.

I have been shooting a lot of skies and clouds recently. I don't know what draws me to it, but for the last couple of months there has been quite a show in the sky and I happen to notice it. Perhaps they come from all the hurricanes we've had in the near past. Although Oklahoma doesn't evacuate or have any danger from hurricanes. Rather it's the disturbance in the jet stream and the influence from the Senate.

"Use the force, Luke," is a phrase I have grown up with. Me and some local shooters use the phrase "Jedi mind trick," to indicate a successful image. The force is all around us, it's what binds us together. We watched Michael Moore's latest horror flick on 9/11 today. We had watched Bowling a few weeks ago. It makes me so proud to be an American. And of the people that We The People have put in Washington. Fear thy neighbor is par.

So, anyway. Besides clouds. This has been a slow month for my photography. A side effect of my new job. I did have a trip to the Ft. Worth Zoo, the best zoo around these parts IMO. Many cloud days. Kendrick Bailey playing his guitar at Mr. Bills. And an Opolis sighting for Pleasant Grove and Student Film.

I have reduced my input to my weblog while building my photoblog. I'm at a point now where I almost don't see a need for both. I will try to manage and update here more regularly.

One last thing. I thought I had retired the Open Sign Series at 100 individuals. But, this weekend I added 10 more.

I've been getting a lot of virus email in the last three days. Be on the lookout for simple subject lines like "Information" or "Document" or "Hi." All of the virus' that I've received have been from domains and people that I know. All contain attachments. The whole email message and attachment are 30.94 to 30.97 kilobytes in size. I don't know what virus it is, but I don't care. Just be smart enough to smell the fishy email and you won't have to care either.

The tale from Coyle. I've been attempting to document as much Oklahoma as I can. You will now find El Reno, Talihina Drive and Cleveland County (I live in this county, the most populated area of it at least, near OU). In addition to Coyle. Next to be posted is the Wichita Mountains near Lawton and Cache. As well as sifting through the mass of images I shot while in Florida.

A new flash, a new 8mp camera body and three new ultra to wide zooms. Lots of new toys to drool over. The new camera, the 20D, will hopefully drive the price of the 10D down to an affordable position. Under $1000 for a used one would be nice. The lenses are not the fastest, but are semi-affordable. Especially interesting is the 10-22mm f/3.5-4.5 USM zoom. I would love to have something in this range. But, $799 is only semi affordable. Ouch.

Tapdig.com is now located at a new server with the same hosting company. The previous server was in Hong Kong. The new server is in the United States of America. I hope this geographic move speeds up access speeds, since most visitors to this site are US. The main purpose for the move is for storage space. I've upgraded from the "Personal Plan" of 333MB to the "Business Plan" of 999MB storage. I can't believe that I've filled up 333MB. That's a lot of pictures. The Gallery says there are 1,762 photos in the system. Some webmasters might cut content to save storage space. I am against this sort of practice. I believe that once something is placed online... it needs to stay there forever. Others link to your stuff, quote your stuff, reference your stuff... I sure hate it when I bookmark something and when I return their stuff is gone or changed. So, I buy more storage. I thought it'd be a horrible experience to move, but due to the fact that both the old and new servers are identical, it was pretty easy. Same OS, same locations for perl, and other programs. Same great service. I wouldn't recommend a server move for everyone. Just as I wouldn't recommend using blosxom as a blogging tool. Unless of course you know perl, apache, htaccess, html, css, and so on. Or you want to learn a few things, which was my case. Now that I have storage space again, look for more frequent updates and new images.

I'm tired. Driving three days with a car full of kids is not at the top of my recommendations for vacationing. So, I've only posted one image from our first night in Florida. The sunset on the beach was spectacular. Photos barely do any justice. I hope to post more images soon.
Gone to Navarre/Destin, Florida, back July 26. See ya.
Images from Band Camp Photos by: http://www.tapdig.com/gallery Event organizers: http://www.oklahomapunkscene.com

The frequent thunderstorms have really been dramatic. I started shooting clouds and I think I'm hooked. It's quite amusing to see them change. One minute there is an awesome shot, seconds later it's gone. Then over my shoulder is another passing monster. The layers of foreground whispies to the far away thunder heads are so nice when they cross each other.
Ambassador Bill played at the Acts of Kindness benefit at Will Rogers Ampitheater last night. Here's a shot of Tonya.

Here's a summary of what's I've been up to: CD review: Citizens Here and Abroad a flyer for a Cheyenne + Locust Avenue show Enon + Mandragora photos The Ills + Red Monroe photos Klipspringer CD release party at a record shop Squeaky Burger photo shoot I started a food photoblog. NHS girls soccer photos El Reno, Oklahoma photos Hagfish photos Red Stripes photos and photo shoot Citizens Here and Abroad + Pacific UV photos In line for processing for the web, coming as soon as I get to it: Klipspringer + ElPaso HotButton photos from 5-20-04 Ambassador Bill + Redbud Revival photos from 5-22-04

There are a couple of bands here in Oklahoma playing a show together. One is called Twenty Minutes to Vegas and the other is Forty Minutes of Hell. 

So, it's my understanding that it takes an hour to get from Vegas to Hell. That's not long.
The problem with "reality" shows it they are not reality. They are, however, cast, edited, produced, written, staged, and promoted. Didn't you know that?

I am almost caught up. Lately, I've posted photos from The Monolith + Josh Cobb and my new favorite band Aveo + American Boyfriends and Hairy Apes BMX + Malachy Papers.

On March 16, I put a counter on gallery. It counts every click. I started it at 1,000. Here we are on April 1, that's half of a month, there have been over 6,500 clicks. That's pretty amazing. I had no idea. I would guess that 500 of those are just me updating and such. But still...

I'm still behind on updating Watermelon Slim, Klipspringer, Donny Vomit, 40 Minutes of Hell, Mermaid Purse (Austin), Redbud Revival, and after tonight we can add The Hex and another 40 Minutes of Hell to the list. That makes 80 Minutes of Hell? Anyway.

In other news, my last day at work is April 6. My first day at the new job is April 16. I should have 9 whole days to catch up on things like processing images.

The "Wampus wins on Jeopardy" watch party was a lot of fun. I think the coolest thing was watching the Hot Freaks, the all GBV cover band, perform their first (semi public) show.

All good friends up there on stage. It was quite a treat. They sure did a good job. When will they play again?

Wampus is such a stud master. The accountant from Norman, OK goes on Jeopardy and becomes a four-day champion. Way to go.

I'm so far behind on photo processing. The photoshop sits idle. Let's see, there's
  • HotFreaks+Wampus031904
  • TheMonolith+JoshCobb032004
  • Aveo+AmericanBoyfriends032204
  • HairyApesBMX+MalachyPapers032304
  • BillHomans(WatermelonSlim)032604
  • Klipspringer+DonnyVomit+40minofHell032704
I'll get right on it mister. After I sleep. I worked 10 hours of overtime these last 2 days. "Must gain rest"

The French Kicks and the Walkmen from the Opolis on 3/14/04. Can you say packed house? It was a packed house. Both bands played with quite the enthusiasm and excitement that I always hope to see out of every band. I was certainly looking forward to this night. And it sure lived up to the billing and hype. I give two thumbs up for both bands.

The band from the Starlight Mints show the night before were at the show, Dressy Bessy. I got to hung out with my new favorite band. Tammy sure is cool.

The big stage at the Diamond Ballroom, two nights in one week. It has been a busy week for touring bands with SXSW travelers stopping in at our local music venues. A big thanks to Andy Nunez for all he does.

I have to say I was really impressed with all three bands this night. I think Dressy Bessy is my new favorite. Sort of a hint of that Liz Phair female-singer-songwriter type of thing and I really dig the CDs. I can't say the performance was very memorable, because I find myself in that photographer zone and with earplugs it is easy to drift beyond the sounds and focus so keenly on just the visuals. I do enjoy the zone. I discovered earplugs are important to a photographer. So many times I find myself pressed against the speaker mains, insides thumping, ears burning... I have to say, Trent Bell did a superb job. He ran sound for the Mints and it was so much better than the first two bands' mix.

The next night was the French Kicks and the Walkmen. No chance to process the images yet... be patient.

First time to the Opolis this month. The Mints are on the road. Final show for the Metered Spirits. What are the chances of me seeing two shows on consecutive nights and both out-of-town bands are from Minnesota? I had thought from Haley's website, without hearing a sound, that she'd be a cross between PJ Harvey and Tori. It was a close comparison. Haley was very soft and somewhat droning. Many patrons said they were fighting the urge to sleep, I think in a good way. I admit, it was a mellow act, but nothing to sleep about. Too bad Metered Spirits are no more. I had not realized how musically gifted Lindsay is. They hit some nice harmonies on vocals. I shoot the Mints tonight at the Diamond. cheers

Be sure and check out OklahomaRock.com. A very thourough listing of shows. And also, my Norman fav. NormanMusicScene.com. And go tell Lindsay to have a great time in Europe.

A 30 mile drive to find some nice punk. It is quite a haul to the Conservatory, but I find it quite enjoyable. The occasion: The Menstural Tramps from Minneapolis, Lesser Humans and 3 of 5.

The Tramps were very friendly and fun to hang out with. They seem to have lots of fun wherever they go. I enjoyed the music and even bought a CD. When Lesser Humans played, I shot a burst sequence of about 6 to 8 images that (when I get around to it) would make a real neat animated gif.

A comment I left at photo_obscura's journal.
I really dig your web site. Great images full of beautiful people. I like your use of simple backgrounds. I was doing a shoot one time and the subject said, "no trees or bushes" which i guess is what motofoto shooters use. I stopped to think. Am I shooting a person or a tree? Ever since then, I try to shoot tighter or minimize the background somehow. I don't do any studio work right now, but your site has encouraged me back in that direction. You do some neat things with the colors/lights in you backgrounds. cool.

A very nice night of lofi, artistic expression. Jeff Klein solo, musician from Austin, played a soulful set. Copouts, Jeff Richardson and Mark Lewellen, played a mix of Locust Avenue songs, unique covers, and perfect duet songs. And I finally saw Cheyenne after missing them on two previous occasions. And of course, all photos from the opolis appear on my opolis photo page.

I started this yahoo group several months ago. This is my first time to promote it. I thought members would just appear, but they have not. Having a place to share techniques, show off your art, and to meet other photoshop users was my intension. I'd recommend using a yahoo email address to join.

Click to subscribe to shopart

I've added a bunch of new photo albums: Klipspringer + Mandragora from Mr. Bills 2/21/04. (should be processed and online later today) Ester Drang + MidLake from the Opolis 2/20/04. Camille Harp from Mr. Bills 2/14/04. The Open Sign series is up to 23 individuals now. I am still current with my photo du jour. An album called Cleveland County. I started a new one dedicated to PhotoShop art. Photos from the Bishop Allen show from the Opolis made it in the Norman Transcript Pop magazine on Friday. My first byline in years. Sort of a review/preview snip. I hope it helps pack the Deli on a Tuesday. The near future looks like more Shop Art, and (mentioned above) a date at the Deli with Bishop Allen, Jonesound, and it appears the Stellas will be there, now, too, on Tuesday night. Also, I'll try to make the Opolis 2 or 3 times this week to expand the Opolis photo archive page. That's it for now, I'll try to post these things one at a time, as they happen. But sometimes I get behind and neglect my lj.
I guess I don't have the time to upload images everyday. I seem to go for about 5 days at once. Perhaps I should rename it "photos du semaine." http://www.tapdig.com/gallery/photodujour

Here are some photos I took near where I live. I have friends here on lj from Canada, FL, CA, MA, NYC, IL, NJ, and of course, Oklahoma. I wanted to show what is near me to those who've never been nearby. cheers. Click on the photo and go to Cleveland County album.

Bishop Allen turned out to be way more entertaining than I had feared. I was expecting a lot more shoegazing and not as much fun. The rest of the crowd seemed hip to what to expect. Many were dancing and even singing along. Wow, a band from NYC has a following in Norman.

Jonesound really impressed me. A very good guitar player, Josh Jones is a Normanite who has moved along. The first few songs, he played solo. Then the band hopped on stage for a few more. Definately singer/songwriter goodness.

A really super night of shooting. In the past, I usually only pull about 10 to 20 shots to post online. This night, I couldn't get it under 50. So much for moderation of host space.

A night full of good music and good people. Which is normally the case at the Opolis. The only thing that sucks is: I still have to be at work at 8AM.

Two shows for Feb. 4:
Jonesound, Bishop Allen - The Opolis
Ambassador Bill w/ All Organic Combo - the Deli
Which should I pick? Both should be a good crowd. I've seen AmBill twice in about a month, so I'd probably go with the Bishop Allen show, besides, it's Opolis...for the club gallery project. Bishop Allen seems like a Strokes-mold band with a hint of the radiohead-flaming lips formula. They're from NYC so it should be good, right? Might not be photogenic because could be shoegazers.

This post inspired by Barb and...
"Remember, journalism is what somebody doesn't want you to print. Everything else is publicity. " -Jim Hall, Beginning Reporting -from rzr_grl's journal today.
I met Barb (from http://www.oklahomapunkscene.com/) last night at the VaGiants show. I noticed her taking notes on a little pad. I was shooting pictures viciously. After the show, I ask her what she's doing. She says oklahomapunkscene.com/ and I say I'm having fun. She should use my pics in her column. She says contact me. During the exchange of contact methods, I ask if she does live journal. She says, "No, it's too confessional." I say, "but there are lots of local music freaks on there. (It's a digital scene.)" I had never thought of lj her way. I thought about it all day. When I saw rzr_grl's post, it seemed to apply. I agree with her, sure. But, there's more to it. I've seen many confessional journals. I've seen purely publicity journals. But there's also the variety and mixed bag. I have friends here that, more or less, do less publicity, but it's hard to label as confessing. I like checking my friends page. I literally had no lj experience until recently. I'm making it my own, as each of you has. I suppose I'm on the publicity side. But it's like politics: varying degrees of parties. Lieberman is a self proclaimed "moderate democrat." What the hell does that mean? He can run against Bush while still supporting the republican beliefs? I must be a moderate publicist.

A punk band from Winnipeg, Manitoba. When I saw them on the line up at The Conservatory, I checked out the VaGiant site and listened to a mp3. I thought it sounded power pop - punk. After seeing the live presentation, and hearing more than one song, I concluded that a better description is power blues - punk. Sort of a roadhouse punk band.

The band presents well with a not shy, in your face lead vocalist, Joanne (aka J-Rod). Just a simple three piece with J-Rod on vocal. I might go as far to say it was the best punk band I've seen on stage since Hagfish, back around 1994. I think that's accurate, but consider that I have not seen very much punk in the 9 year span since then.

I became aware of maybe a sexual theme. VaGiant could be a play on the word vagina. The album I got is titled "Short and Hard." And the first song on it is "Hot Box." To top it all off, the singer wore a little babydoll dress which came up a short. Meaning, she wore purple pasties to keep from getting arrested. She expressed her thanks for being in Oklahoma's tropical environment, January, 15 degrees F. They had escaped the -30 degrees C from Winnipeg.

Their manager had told me by email that Joanne would be quite photogenic. She was right. And not at all shy about it. I took 130 images. I'd say 50 or so are worth looking at (due to poor lighting, as usual). I've gone ahead and posted two on my photodujour. I'll add them to my music gallery very soon.

Note: I regret to have missed the opening acts. The 45 minute drive from my house left me late, and the show was early.

I did get some CSS to work for me. I actually converted my entire blosxom site to no tables. Not a single table. It's all fine, but then I want to go make it do something else, which I have no idea how to. 

I have navigation floating at the top left. I'd like to have a similar box at the bottom left. Same width, just at the bottom, with background in between. CSS helpers would be nice. I will deal with the XHTML part of this later.

Here's my new conquest: http://blog.tapdig.com/
And here's what it used to look like: http://blog.tapdig.com/cgi-bin/blosxom.cgi/index.html

I put the first session relults online from the "OPEN" sign series. It was a hoot. No one seemed to mind and no one revolted. A total of 7 participants. I'll attempt to continue this series next time I visit the Opolis.
Picks of the bands last night, Fellowship Students and Metered Spirit are also uploaded.

Shot some more bands. I've started a collection of images of people in front of the "OPEN" sign at the Opolis. It's been fun. Some nights are no smoking inside, so the crowd varies in front of the sign. I got 7 shots tonight. Get some sleep, process images some other time.

This was a fun night of shooting. My goal that night was to shoot 300 images. I came very close, over 250. The bad part is, the success rate was what I had expected. "Lucky shot syndrome" is usually about 10% I'd guess.

Faced with difficult lighting, worse than usual at times, I tried some experimentation with flash and long exposures. I seemed to have good luck at 1600, 4 seconds, f5.6. Several times I covered the lens with my hand knowing that the exposure was too long. I guess it's a form of painting with light.

Thinking about Angela. I turned the review off this night. I had gotten so used to looking at the small rendering of an image in that LCD window after every shutter. I felt like Luke by the end of the night, "Let the force flow." Ends up, I did pull off several jedi mind tricks.

The crowd was full of beautiful people and my experiments continued into the black hole of standing-room-only.

I made it out to see Brian Jonestown Massacre and Mandragora. It was a good night of music. I was attempting to shoot 300 photos. I think I came close. I was experiementing with long exposures with flash. Looked like mixed results after a quick review last night. That's what I was expecting with my "lucky shot" approach. I'll post some images soon... 
It is encouraging the support and response I received from Andy (Opolis) and Jeremy (Mandragora). I'm glad to be hooking up with club owners and band members to be able to add a little art to their web sites, etc.
